Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Integrating Learning Resources for Information Security Research and Education (iSECURE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is linking and integrating multi-media teaching materials (slides, videos and textbooks) used in Information Security courses based on a security ontology. The semantic linking of the multimedia course materials allows students to search and compose multimedia and interactive course materials based on the content, medium and learning styles, enabling flexible personalized learning. To achieve these goals, the project is focusing on several research tasks: (1) Segmenting and annotating learning media based on their learning content, (2) Building a Security ontology to be used for annotating and querying of the learning objects, (3) Adapting lecture content to student learning styles, and (4) Evaluating the usability and effectiveness of the linked multimedia security learning system.

The technology and methodology that is being developed by this project, including the ontology builder for a given learning topic, the semantic segmentation of multimedia learning objects, the search, and personalization of learning objects, can be adapted to any course. The outcome of this project helps students build upon existing knowledge as they are being introduced to unfamiliar material, by creating subject specific searches of all course content. This changes the way students learn by making course content more organized, interactive, and instantly accessible while adding individualization options. Students are able to fill gaps in their previous learning instantly by integrating search results into their current studying. By having instant access to learning, and experiencing a truly interactive, individualized learning environment, students are less likely to be overwhelmed by course materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project among three institutions (NJIT, CUNY/College of Staten Island, and Montclair State University) aims to facilitate cyber-security learning and education for millennial students, by designing methodologies and tools to link diverse multi-modal online learning materials and making them accessible according to security concepts and semantic relationships. Our approach was to develop a security ontology and a multi-modal course repository that integrates all the multimedia learning material and allows the course material to be searched on their learning content.

Intellectual Merit: 

The intellectual merit of this project is three-fold:

1 Search through Security Ontology

To create a knowledge base of cyber security learning resources and to support the search for the resources, we have developed a cyber security ontology (SO) that can provide students with domain knowledge of cyber security concepts and relationships.  The semi-automated cyber security ontology engineering uses bootstrapping and text extraction methods to recognize the cyber security concepts from textbooks and Web pages. We also developed an ontology guided co-occurrence analysis method to identify the relationships among security concepts, by extracting sentences from a cyber security textbook. We have also designed and implemented the security experts tool (SOX) that allows experts to insert and edit concepts and relationships in the cyber security ontology and the security ontology browser (SOB) for students to navigate the domain knowledge structure and to learn the definition of each security concept via the hierarchical taxonomic structure among concepts, and learn about related concepts via the horizontal relationships among them.   

2. Ultimate Course Search

Multimedia is the main support for online learning materials and the size of multimedia learning materials is growing with the popularity of online programs offered by Universities. Ultimate Course Search (UCS) is a tool that aims to provide efficient search of course materials. UCS integrates slides, lecture videos and textbook content into a single platform with search capabilities. The keywords extracted from the textbook index and the power-point slides are the basis of the indexing scheme. The slides are indexed on the keywords and the videos are indexed on the slides. The correspondence between the slides and video segments is established using the meta-data provided by the video recording software when available and by image processing techniques. We have investigated different search techniques

The UCS tool was utilized in traditional face-to-face and hybrid sections of a university Introduction to Security course to determine effectiveness in reducing high attrition rates. The attrition rate for the face-to-face course utilizing UCS (experimental group) was 13% as compared to the attrition rate of 41% for mean the face-to-face course without access to UCS (control group). In the face-to-face sections, the mean final exam score was higher for the experimental section (150.86/200) than for the control section (144.57/200). Interestingly, the standard deviation for the final exam scores was 17.59 for the experimental section and 47.60 for the control section. Thus, the students that had access to UCS scored higher grades, and the grades were closer together (i.e. no extreme low grades) than students that did not have access to UCS. Students found that UCS helped them study for exams, complete projects, and review notes.

Broad Impact:  The way of searching learning material is different from classical document and multimedia search in the sense that what the user is looking for is where the search keywords are better explained. We have explored and developed novel search techniques that can be applied any application where the data is represented by points in high dimensional spaces. Ultimate Course Search is a general course material storage and search tool that can be used on any course. It was used to support a hybrid Career Counselling course at Montclair State University, as well as traditional face-to-face and hybrid sections of a Security course at NJIT. Regardless of the course or type of delivery, students found UCS to be helpful in their learning and studying.

Online and hybrid courses are becoming the norm in higher education, and students often prefer the time flexibility of these courses. One of the negatives of these formats, and one of the reasons for high attrition of online classes, is the inability to find information and study materials in the course. UCS will change online learning by increasing accessibility of this material, enabling students to individualize their learning and focus their studying. From a teaching standpoint, all information will be searchable, allowing assignments to move across courses and semesters. Students in advanced classes who are lacking in earlier content will be able to access that content, and learn any missing material. This will reduce redundant questions and increase student engagement in material. Thus, the teaching and the learning of content will change, and become more individualized and more flexible, enhancing learning.
